conclusion: The conductor rod MN is initially at rest, the spring is in its natural length, and the conductor rod MN has an initial horizontal leftward velocity.
The conductor rod MN is subjected to the force of gravity (mg) and the force of the spring.
The spring force is given by F_s = kx, where k is the spring constant and x is the displacement of the spring.
The gravitational force is given by F_g = mg.
The spring force is proportional to the displacement of the spring, so F_s ∝ x.
The gravitational force is constant and does not change with the displacement of the spring.
The Joule heat Q generated on the resistor R between AB is given by Q = 1/2mv^2, where m is the mass of the conductor rod and v is the initial horizontal velocity.
The force F on the conductor rod MN is the sum of the gravitational force and the spring force.
The force F is given by F = mg + kx.
At the initial moment, the conductor rod MN is at rest, the spring is in its natural length, the gravitational force is mg, and the spring force is kx.
After a period of time, the conductor rod MN moves to the rightmost end for the first time.
The spring force is k(L-x) (since the spring is compressed by x).
The gravitational force is mg.
The Ampere force F_A on the conductor rod MN is given by F_A = BIL/R, where I is the current in the conductor rod.
The current I is given by I = v/R, where v is the velocity of the conductor rod.
The velocity v is given by v = √(2gx), where g is the acceleration due to gravity and x is the displacement of the spring.
The conductor rod MN has moved to the rightmost end for the first time.
The spring force is k(L-x).
The gravitational force is mg.
The Ampere force F_A is given by F_A = BIL/R.
The final equation for the Ampere force F_A is F_A = BIL/mv^2.
